Every time MercadoLibre $MELI stumbles, the market reacts as if Latin Americaâ€™s dominant e-commerce and fintech ecosystem has suddenly forgotten how to grow. So when the stock slipped more than 9% since my last analysis, I wasnâ€™t alarmed I was interested. MercadoLibreâ€™s recent dip isnâ€™t a thesis-breaker; itâ€™s the kind of mispricing long-term investors wait for.

But the strategic foundation the expanding user base, the accelerating adoption of credit products, and the deepening integration of payments, lending, logistics, and commerce remains intact. In fact, several developments suggest that MELI is positioning itself for an even more powerful decade of growth.

A Platform That Is Becoming a Financial Operating System for Latin America

MercadoLibreâ€™s scope is already enormous: 650 million potential consumers across 18 countries. But what keeps surprising me is how efficiently the company is turning this reach into a self-reinforcing closed-loop ecosystem.

The Marketplace still anchors the business, but this is no longer just an e-commerce story. MercadoLibre has effectively built the rails for digital finance in the region. Mercado Pago has evolved far beyond paymentsm today it handles peer-to-peer transfers, bill payments, mobile purchases, and installment plans. Users arenâ€™t just buying things theyâ€™re managing their financial lives through the platform.

And then thereâ€™s lending. MELIâ€™s $11 billion credit portfolio a staggering 83% YoY jump isnâ€™t simply a new revenue line. It is the logical extension of MELIâ€™s data advantage. The company knows how buyers shop, how sellers operate, and how cash flows through the ecosystem. In markets with thin or unreliable credit histories, that information is gold.

Credit cards and consumer loans naturally cycle back into the Marketplace, processed through Mercado Pago, and settled in the userâ€™s high-yield account or crypto wallet. MELI touches every part of the transaction stack, from financing to payment to fulfillment. That level of vertical integration is rare anywhere in global tech, let alone in an underpenetrated region with limited incumbents.

The next major step direct paycheck deposits via Mercado Pago is the catalyst no one is properly pricing in. It locks users into MELI for daily financial life and positions the company as a de facto digital bank. Brazil already supports this feature, but Mexico remains the regulatory hurdle. When MELI receives that banking license, the companyâ€™s fintech adoption curve could steepen dramatically.

Strengthening the Core Marketplace at a Strategic Moment

The company isnâ€™t standing still on the commerce side either. MELI is sunsetting Mercado Shops and replacing it with â€œMi PÃ¡gina,â€ forcing merchants to build storefronts within the main Marketplace instead of on separate standalone sites. This is a strategically sharp move: fewer external customer touchpoints mean better user data, more ad impressions, and more opportunities to sell financial products.

The new search algorithm is another under-the-radar but important upgrade. By ranking sellers based on a mix of pricing, speed, and customer experience, MELI is essentially rewarding the merchants who strengthen the Marketplaceâ€™s network effect and filtering out noise. With competition intensifying across Latin America especially from rapidly scaling players in Brazil and Mexico this quality-first algorithm is a smart defensive measure.

The companyâ€™s ability to acquire users is also noteworthy. MELI added 7.8 million new buyers in Q3 alone most of them younger users drawn through influencer-driven affiliate marketing. These demographics matter. Younger cohorts are more likely to adopt fintech services quickly, transact often, and become multi-product users. Thatâ€™s how lifetime value expands.

Argentina: A Hard Market, but MELI Is Navigating It Better Than Expected

Argentina remains a challenge politically, economically, and financially. High rates are hurting discretionary spending. Shipping and funding costs are rising. And regulatory unpredictability always lingers in the background.

But what stands out is what didnâ€™t happen: non-performing loans barely increased despite recession conditions and policy volatility. MELI doubling its loan book in Argentina without a spike in defaults tells me something important its underwriting models are working even in the regionâ€™s most unstable environment. That speaks volumes about the defensiveness of MELIâ€™s fintech franchise.

Financial Performance: Growth Still Outruns the Headwinds

MercadoLibreâ€™s Q3 numbers reaffirm the companyâ€™s operational strength. Revenue increased nearly 40% YoY to $7.4 billion. Operating income rose 30% to $724 million. Commerce revenue grew 33% YoY, driven by a 28% GMV surge and broader purchase frequency. Meanwhile, fintech revenue jumped nearly 49% YoY to $2.2 billion a function of broader payment adoption and a meaningful jump in loan origination.

But this isnâ€™t structural erosion; itâ€™s a function of MELI expanding services that are inherently margin-dilutive in early stages but accretive over time. Lending, especially, follows a predictable pattern: new cohorts compress NIMAL (net interest margin after losses), then steadily mature into high-return segments.

MELIâ€™s Brazil cohorts its most mature credit market are already at breakeven. Mexico and Argentina will follow as MELI continues to refine risk models and scale customer repayment histories.

E-commerce in Latin America still has years of runway; MELI is building infrastructure ahead of the demand curve, not behind it.

Free cash flow grew $400 million YoY despite sequential declines tied to fintech inflows. When a company can expand CapEx aggressively and still expand FCF, it signals both discipline and underlying demand strength.

Using a 3% terminal growth rate and a 10-year projection period, the updated DCF yields an intrinsic equity value of about $142 billion, or roughly $2,806 per share. That implies nearly 36% upside from current levels.

Even after modeling temporary profitability compression, the valuation case remains strong.

MELI is strengthening its core, widening its fintech moat, improving seller quality, and planting seeds in categories it previously underpenetrated.

Short-term volatility doesnâ€™t invalidate long-term compounding especially not for a company still adding millions of new users, expanding payments penetration, maturing its credit portfolio, and investing in infrastructure with genuine competitive purpose.
